Not our mystery guest again.   Not real?  A beat as she only looks back.   What, like some kind of ghost?   Showing you what?   Maybe it was one of them did the handy work on those Greeks.   Victims of what?   That much I think we've already established.   What's that supposed to mean?   Why you? How come the rest of us haven't seen these people?   Well. Getting off this ship's exactly what we're trying to do.  Short of that, I don't know what else to tell you.  She only looks back at him, then into the fire.   Do me a favor and wake up Dodge. He's next on.  She starts to get up.   And Epps?  She stands, looking back at him.   You can tell the others about this. But, for my money, I think it's best you keep it to yourself.  She holds there a beat longer, then turns, walking off.   You're late.   (handing him the shotgun Don't fall asleep.    Dodge?   Murphy to Epps.   Either of you seen Dodge?  She looks to Greer who shakes his head.   He's not on deck and I can't raise him on the radio.   He took the shotgun and a light.   Alright. We stay together. Nobody goes any further than earshot.    Murphy to Dodge. Murphy to Dodge. Over.   Murphy to Dodge. Do you copy? Over.   Epps? You there?    As he moves along as well, eyes open.   Greer?   So whoever did this now has our shotgun.   Leave him till we can get some help.  From now on, nobody comes down here.   Leave it.   You think whoever did this is reasonable?   Nobody's going anywhere with that gold now. Anybody tries to board, we'll know about it.  You can do what you want, Greer. But neither of us is gonna risk saving your ass down here if it comes to that.   Must've been him all along.  Murphy and Epps look on from the outside in the promenade.   Smashed the radio. Scuttled the boat. Killed Dodge. Would've killed you. He's off his nut, no doubt there.  They watch him in silence a moment as Greer mutters and bobs.   What do you think?   Over the gold.   Crazy with greed. Not crazy. Not like him.  A beat as Epps looks off. In the window Greer drags his hideously distorted face over the glass, the blood from his wounds smearing in broad red streaks.   We lash a few of these together it might get us far enough into the shipping lanes to be rescued.  A beat as they look on at the rotting hull.   Hard to say which is worse, staying here or taking our chances in open water.   It's not the weather I'm worried about. The wrong current could drag us as far as the Aleutians before we come across another boat.   Epps to Murphy.  Only WHITE NOISE COMES BACK.   We hit land.   We're in an island chain. It's only a matter of time before we hit another one.   Let's get the hell out of here.   It should be enough to get us to one of those islands. Gimme a hand, wouldya?  She joins him and they lift it off its stand, taking it to the rail.   Prop it here. We need to pull these braces off. There's a hammer on the stand. There.  Epps crosses back to the stands.   I'll take that.  A beat as she looks to Murphy.   It was only a matter of time before somebody killed somebody.  You saw it coming as well as I did. Dodge had his plans, starting with scuttling the boat. And Greer too, except he went nuts. Couldn't take it, I guess. Could've happened in the middle of downtown Anchorage. But did it make him any less dangerous? I don't think so.   The way I figure it, it was them or me. I thought putting Dodge up on that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a little time. Made it look like whoever killed those Greeks was still around. But it's just us on this ship. Us and your... spirit friends.   I didn't want it to turn out this way.   I think I see it pretty well.   I know a little bit about human nature and what I've seen only confirms that.   I think maybe you been on this boat a little too long, with all that supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's nothing supernatural about greed. And that's what it comes down to, pure and simple.   I wish I could believe that. Either way, you know what I've done. I've got no choice.  He raises the shotgun.   I'm sorry.  He prepares to fire, when a CONCUSSION ROCKS THE SHIP. Epps ducks and Murphy fires, a spatter of buckshot shredding the vent behind her. A SCREECHING OF METAL DEEP IN THE SHIP SOUNDS as she gets up, diving for cover as Murphy shuttles the gun again.   There's no reason to make this any more difficult than it has to be.    Murphy climbs down a ladder to the lower decks.    Murphy follows, when A RUMBLING SOUND CAN BE HEARD.    Murphy slows and finally stops.    Murphy stops where he is to see water rushing in at the end of the passage. He begins backing away.    Murphy moves down the passageway, coming to the cargo compartment.    As the ship dips lower, the rushing water forms an eddy that pulls at Murphy. Murphy struggles, too heavy to resist as he is pulled closer and closer to the sucking maw that is the smokestack's opening.  The ship sinks further and Murphy is pulled to the edge of the stack. He frantically grabs for something to hold on to, without success, until he is finally pulled into the smoke stack and sucked into the bowels of the ship by the rushing water.
